page.title: 10Buildings, Turvey
page.content: Much of the village between the bridgeand Turvey Abbeyhas been designated a conservation areaand contains many listed buildings (protected from demolition or alteration which would spoil their character). The limestone buildings were built in 18th and 19th centurieswhen the Higgins family rebuilt run down cottages on the public way. Many have interesting gable ends and barge boards and tall brick chimney stacks. One of the finest buildings is the Church of All Saints, dating back to AD 981. Last enlarged in 1856 with the addition of the chancel, sanctuary and choir stalls. Turvey Abbey is Jacobean and a listed building. A statue of Jonah and his wife stand on an island in front of the Mill. There was a railway station up until 1962.
